In $\triangle ABC$, $AB=AC$, so $\triangle ABC$ is an isosceles triangle.
$\angle ABC = \angle ACB = \frac{180^\circ - 20^\circ}{2} = 80^\circ$.
In $\triangle ACD$, $AC=AD$, so $\triangle ACD$ is an isosceles triangle.
$\angle ACD = \angle ADC = \frac{180^\circ - 20^\circ}{2} = 80^\circ$.
$\angle BCD = \angle ACB + \angle ACD = 80^\circ + 80^\circ = 160^\circ$.
In $\triangle BCD$,
$\angle BDC = 180^\circ - (\angle CBD + \angle BCD) = 180^\circ - (80^\circ + 160^\circ) = 180^\circ - 240^\circ$. This is not possible.
We should have $\angle BCD = \angle ACB - \angle ACD = 80^\circ - 80^\circ = 0^\circ$, which is incorrect.
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle ABC = \angle ACB = 80^\circ$.
In $\triangle ACD$, $\angle ACD = \angle ADC = 80^\circ$.
$\angle BCD = \angle ACB + \angle ACD = 80^\circ + 80^\circ = 160^\circ$.
$\angle BDC = 180^\circ - (\angle DBC + \angle BCD)$.
By the Law of Sines in $\triangle ABC$, $\frac{BC}{\sin 20^\circ} = \frac{AC}{\sin 80^\circ}$.
By the Law of Sines in $\triangle ACD$, $\frac{CD}{\sin 20^\circ} = \frac{AC}{\sin 80^\circ}$.
$\angle BCD = 160^\circ$.
In $\triangle BCD$, $\angle BDC = 180^\circ - (\angle DBC + \angle BCD)$.
$\angle BCD = 160^\circ$ and $\angle DBC = 80^\circ$, so $\angle BDC = 180^\circ - (80^\circ + 160^\circ)$, which is impossible.
Let $\angle BCD = \angle ACB - \angle ACD = 80^\circ - 80^\circ = 0^\circ$. This is wrong.
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle ABC = \angle ACB = 80^{\circ}$.
In $\triangle ACD$, $\angle ACD = \angle ADC = 80^{\circ}$.
$\angle BCD = \angle ACB + \angle ACD = 80^{\circ} + 80^{\circ} = 160^{\circ}$.
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle ABC + \angle ACB = 180 - 20 = 160$.
In $\triangle BCD$, $\angle BDC = 180 - (\angle DBC + \angle BCD)$.

By the Law of Sines, $\frac{BC}{\sin 20^{\circ}} = \frac{AC}{\sin 80^{\circ}} = \frac{AD}{\sin 80^{\circ}} = \frac{CD}{\sin 80^{\circ}}$.
$BC = CD$.
$\angle BDC = 180^{\circ} - 100^{\circ} = 80^{\circ}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{20}$
